Carbon farming is put forward as one of the upsides of climate action for farmers but an EU carbon farming scheme is not expected to come into full operation until 2030. It is hoped farming practices that remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and contribute to the climate neutrality objective will be rewarded through schemes officially verified by the EU.

Global soil experts met recently at the Wageningen Soil Conference in the Netherlands. Speakers emphasised that claims of sustainable carbon sequestration must be substantiated, using soil samples and satellite data or models. Tessa van der Voort of the Nutrient Management Institute in Wageningen said you need a baseline measurement, and you must be able to determine that additionally, stored carbon does not seep away. With other complications also, she warned that research costs of carbon farming may well outweigh the compensation farmers are given, hence nullifying its potential.

On the plus side, Ms Van der Voort gave details of the convenient SoilCASTOR measuring method and device that can rapidly determine the amount of carbon in soil samples. SoilCASTOR has won an international innovation Carbon Challenge.

Even as the EU investigates how carbon farming might be regulated, rules are lacking in the voluntary carbon credit schemes already established around the world.

"It's a bit like the Wild West at the moment," said Ms Van der Voort, citing considerable differences in the quality of carbon certs, with excellent quality standards at some organisations, but other credits sometimes sold without proper research or quality standards.

Nonetheless, storing carbon in soil is a good idea, she said. "The effect on the climate may be limited, but carbon storage benefits soil health and resilience against climate change."

Carbon farming is about sequestering carbon, which is needed alongside reducing greenhouse gas emissions, if climate goals are to be achieved. Farmers and scientists know carbon can be stored in the soil by not ploughing, by growing cover crops after the harvest, by increasing permanent grassland, by agroforestry, and by restoring wetlands.

Already, farmers who use these methods sell carbon certificates to businesses seeking to become climate-neutral, through voluntary carbon markets.

The offset market was worth around 2bn in 2021, and is forecast to reach 10bn to 40bn by 2030, in value of offset credits representing avoidance or removal of carbon emissions.

Environmental groups say offsets allow companies to appear to take climate action when in reality they are not cutting emissions.

The European Parliament plans to ban the use of environmental claims based solely on carbon offsetting schemes from next year.

Unfortunately, declining demand for offsets is bad news for poorer nations such as Kenya, which seeks to become a hub for trading carbon offsets based mostly on tree planting.

Despite these question marks over carbon storage, the EU promotes it. The EU legislative proposal to ensure high-quality EU-certified carbon removals was published in 2022. Certification methodologies would be developed in consultation with experts, and a harmonised certification framework implemented in member states.

urn:contentItem:671F-1Y11-JCBW-N2RF-00000-00Inside the EU's carbon farming plans2022-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMING;NEWSPg. 8Inside the EU's carbon farming plansCredits may not be issued for forestry plantations and existing carbon already stored on farms, under Commission's new proposalsCiaran Moran

New EU carbon credits may not be issued for forestry plantations and the existing carbon already stored on farms, it has been revealed.

The European Union has outlined more details on how it plans to certify removals of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

The Commission's proposal, if approved by EU countries and lawmakers, would lay the groundwork for a government-approved certificate for carbon removals.

Brussels said it will now develop laws containing detailed criteria for specific types of removals, for example farming methods that suck CO2 into natural ecosystems.

The proposal lays down requirements for the third-party verification and certification of carbon removals, the management of certification schemes, and the functioning of registries.

Specifically, carbon removal activities need to meet four criteria: Quantification They must be measured in an accurate way and deliver unambiguous carbon removal benefits.

The additional carbon removals generated by an activity (compared to a baseline) should outweigh any emissions that were produced as a consequence of the implementation of the activity over its whole lifecycle.

The 'net carbon removal benefit' should be quantified in a robust and accurate way. Additionality They must go beyond standard practices and what is required by law.

The preferred way to prove additionality is to set a "standardised" baseline that accurately reflects the standard practices and the regulatory and market conditions in which the activity takes place.

This also has the advantage of recognising the early efforts of land managers and industries that already engaged in carbon removal activities in the past.

To ensure ambition over time, the standardised baseline should be periodically updated. Long-term storage They must ensure that the carbon removed is stored for as long as possible and the risk of release of carbon should be minimised.

The certificates will clearly account for the duration of carbon storage, and distinguish permanent storage from temporary storage.

SustainabilIty They must have a neutral impact on, or generate a co-benefit for, other environmental objectives such as biodiversity, climate change adaptation, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, water quality, zero pollution or the circular economy.

The Commission said it will prioritise the development of "tailored certification methodologies" on carbon farming activities that provide significant co-benefits for biodiversity.

At the same time, it said practices such as forest monocultures, that produce harmful effects for biodiversity should not be eligible for certification. Carbon farming The Commission said carbon farming includes farming practices that remove CO2 from the atmosphere and contribute to the climate neutrality objective.

An example cited was the rewetting of peatlands. Others include: ¦ Afforestation and reforestation that respect ecological principles favourable to biodiversity and enhanced sustainable forest management including biodiversity-friendly practices and adaptation of forests to climate change.

¦ Agroforestry and other forms of mixed farming combining woody vegetation (trees or shrubs) with crop and/or animal production systems on the same land. ¦ Use of catch crops, cover crops, conservation tillage and increasing landscape features: protecting soils, reducing soil loss by erosion and enhancing soil organic carbon on degraded arable land.

¦ Targeted conversion of cropland to fallow or of setaside areas to permanent grassland. Use of carbon credits The Commission said carbon removal certificates can be used for results-based rewards by private or public sources.

It outlined several examples including: ¦ Food companies can reward farmers for higher carbon removals that result from more carbon storage in soils or other climatefriendly practices such as agroforestry.

While farmers will benefit from additional income, food companies can credibly document their carbon footprint.

It will be easier for consumers and investors to compare the food companies' climate claims thanks to harmonised certification rules.

¦ Public authorities or private investors that want to finance innovative carbon removal projects or procure carbon removals - such as through reverse public auctions or advance market commitments - can use the certification rules to better compare the offers and reward the projects based on the amount of the certified removals.

Regional authorities can finance the establishment or enlargement of nature parks through the sale of carbon removal certificates, monetising both the climate and biodiversity benefits.

urn:contentItem:69G3-GKC1-JCBW-N0JT-00000-00Don't just dismiss forestry - the payments are good and a lot of the criticisms are myths2023-10-24T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMING;NEWSPg. 14Don't just dismiss forestry - the payments are good and a lot of the criticisms are mythsRICHARD HACKETT

The wide-ranging new forestry schemes offer some compelling rates of payment. The forestry sector has suffered greatly over the last few years and now needs a real PR boost to get it back to its rightful place as a viable land-use option.

The schemes are not perfect. The replanting obligation remains, which I think is an impediment toward a big increase in forestry planted in 'good' agricultural land.

I also have yet to be convinced of any merit to agroforestry. It seems to me a recipe to create bad grazing land and bad forestry. As the late Dr Paddy Barry, an expert in weed control used to say, "you can't grow two crops in the one field".

Nevertheless, the option of forestry deserves consideration by many farmers, for at least a portion of their land.

Consider the Native Forest on Farms and/or Native Forest for Water Protection schemes, where up to 2ha can be planted without a licence. These programmes can provide the annual premia equivalent to an ACRES scheme, for 10 years, for 2ha, and they are tax-free.

As an owner of a small piece of forestry, I find that two of the main criticisms trotted about forestry are simply not true: The first is that a Sitka spruce forest creates a 'green desert' of 'a sterile lifeless landscape'. After planting, from years 1-5, the length of an ACRES scheme, the forest resembles a traditional hay meadow of a proliferation of grasses and wild flowers.

From years 7-17, OK the place is bit dark and grim, but from first thinnings to maturity, (year 40-45), nature again prevails as light gets to the base of the trees. Mosses, ferns, wild flowers, red squirrels, pine martens and many other flora and fauna colonise these quiet spaces.

The development of continuous cover forestry overcomes the scarring effect of clearfell and allows for a balanced equilibrium of trees to develop, all of commercial-grade timber.

The second mistruth is that planting a forest removes the farmer from the land and cuts the linkage between producer and the produce. But the development of a long-term valuable asset like quality timber requires ongoing maintenance and improvement that is best carried out by the landowners themselves on an ongoing basis.

Weeds need to be controlled, drains and boundaries maintained and hedgerows cut back. Training and tooling up allows for opening of inspection tracks, pruning, removal of some firewood, up to taking on some thinning.

I have yet to see a forest owner walk though their forest and not find something to do on their land. The best is that most work is not immediately time-critical: if a job can't be done today, sure it might be better weather in a month's time to do it.

Time spent in the forest is uniquely satisfying in such a quiet natural environment, all in the knowledge that any work done is building towards a long-term goal of high-quality timber production.

However, there are some concerns. It's the season of the púca, and if you want to be truly terrified, get your eye in on the effects of ash die-back on our hedgerows as you drive around.

True, many hedgerow trees, planted as part of the RDS planting schemes many decades ago, have reached the end of their natural life and are dying anyway. But the level of infection in some areas is alarming.

Dead-standing trees don't stay standing for long and a comprehensive removal programme will have to be put in place soon, before tragedy occurs.

Richard Hackett is an agronomist based in North Co Dublin and is a member of the ACA and ITCA

urn:contentItem:68BY-RDB1-DYRW-V10F-00000-00EU'sambitionto usher in carbon farming quickly2023-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITYPg. 14EU'sambitionto usher in carbon farming quicklyStephen Cadogan

Carbon farming may become a viable agricultural enterprise sooner than expected after the European Parliament called for the proposed monitoring, reporting, and verification framework for verified emission and removal data from farms to be put in place well before 2026.

The commission is developing carbon certification methodologies, in consultation with experts and stakeholders, which will be harmonised across the EU.

It is not anticipated to come into full operation until 2030, but the European Parliament in a plenary session asked the commission to ensure verified emission and removal data from farms are available well before 2026. Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) said agriculture and forestry should play a significant role in achieving the EU carbon removal target from the land use sector.

Increasing the amount of carbon in the soil also brings multiple benefits, including improved soil quality and fertility.

According to MEPs, carbon farming is an opportunity for farmers to transform their business model and to better reward those who are voluntarily engaging in a transition towards agro-ecological and sustainable agroforestry practices that also promote biodi-versity.

As MEPs supported a sustainable carbon cycles resolution with 323 votes to 257, rapporteur Alexander Bern-huber (Austria) said: "We support sustainable carbon cycles and the concept of carbon farming, which can actively contribute to climate change mitigation. Carbon farming can become another source of income for European agriculture and forestry. We also believe it should be voluntary and incentive-driven, without unnecessary bureaucracy and obligations."

The EU becoming carbon neutral by 2050 means that each single tonne of carbon dioxide equivalent emitted into the atmosphere will have to be neutralised by a tonne removed from the atmosphere. The Parliament was responding to citizens' expectations to introduce a certified system of carbon removal as part of safe and sustainable food production.

The Farm Europe think-tank also says that the EU's ongoing regulatory process on carbon removals certification is absolutely key, to achieving EU climate ambitions.

The Farm Europe experts said farmers were the first solar operators, in the form of photosynthesis (plants turning sunlight into energy by converting carbon dioxide and water into food) without any solar panels having to be imported into the EU.

urn:contentItem:68RT-CW31-DYRW-V2XB-00000-00New 'crucial' knowledge transfer programme opens for applications2023-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8New 'crucial' knowledge transfer programme opens for applicationsKathleen O'Sullivan

The new knowledge transfer (KT) programme under CAP has opened for applications.

The programme will allow for knowledge exchange and innovation between advisors, farmers, and other stakeholders, Minister for Agriculture Charlie McConalogue said, and will play a "crucial role" in helping farmers to meet current and future challenges.

"This new programme will build on what was achieved by its predecessor under the 2014-2020 Rural Development Programme," Mr McConalogue said.

"It will also contribute to the wider development of the Agricultural Knowledge and Innovation Systems [AKIS] by harnessing the knowledge of all those who work in the agri-food chain.

"I look forward to advisors and farmers engaging with the new KT programme - to the benefit of Irish farm businesses - as this is where the programme's success will be measured."

Minister of state Martin Heydon added that the new programme will "provide an important avenue to support farmers to access information across a wide range of topics, including environmental sustainability, digital and smart technologies, and succession planning".

"I am particularly pleased that farm health, safety, and wellbeing has been included as a priority topic in the new programme," he said.

"Peer learning is a powerful driver of behavioural change and has been shown to be an effective method of improving safety on farms.

"This ensures the programme covers not only economic and environmental sustainability, but also social sustainability on farms."

There is a two-step application process.

Expressions of interest to act as a KT facilitator from FAS-approved advisors are accepted online via agfood.ie by September 1.

If approved, the KT facilitator will be invited to submit an application for a KT group and nominate the group participants on the online KT system by October 31.

Participants will receive reimbursement to the amount of 750 per annum where all the requirements of the programme have been met.

Facilitators will receive 500 per annum per participant in their group(s) where all the requirements of the programme have been met.

Each KT group can have a maximum of 20 participants and each participant must attend eight group meetings and one-to-ones with the KT facilitator each year of the three-year programme.

This programme is separate to a forestry-specific Knowledge Transfer Programme also announced by Minister of State Pippa Hackett this month.

The Forestry Knowledge Transfer Group (KTG) Scheme has reopened for 2023. The aim of the scheme is to increase awareness of sustainable forest management amongst forest owners and includes topics covering continuous cover forestry, agroforestry, and building forest resilience, according to Ms Hackett.

"By participating in the scheme, our target group - forest owners - gain additional knowledge to help them gain expertise in managing their forest over its lifetime," she said.

The KTGs are led by a professional forester and encourage participants to engage with forestry groups and professionals.

urn:contentItem:65XJ-C851-DYRW-V2WY-00000-00Forestry - sustainably integrating trees on the farm2022-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMINGPg. 11Forestry - sustainably integrating trees on the farmTom Houlihan - Teagasc

New forest and woodland creation can deliver a wide range of future benefits on your farm.

Whether small or larger areas are involved, setting clear objectives and timely planning are central to success. Do you wish to explore options to enhance the farm environment? Is the provision of additional farm income or a tax-efficient future pension fund a strong priority? How will a future farm forest fit in with current enterprises and future plans?

Selecting suitable planting categories

Good planning is essential to ensure tree species selection matches the prevailing soil and site conditions for new farm forest projects. The current Forestry Programme, administered by the Department of Agriculture Food and the Marine (DAFM), continues up to the end of 2022. Work is also progressing on a successor Forestry Programme which will be available in 2023.

The current programme incorporates 12 Grant and Premium Categories (called GPCs), offering a range of forest options on suitable farm locations. These include productive conifers and broadleaves, native woodland and agroforestry. All new forest planting requires 15% of the land area planted to be dedicated to involbiodiversity enhancement (e.g. retained habitats, hedgerows and open areas). Every tree species, conifer or broadleaf, has its own unique biodiversity characteristics. The more diversity of species that occur in a forest, the more biodiversity and ecosystem benefits are likely to be delivered.

New farm forests can incorporate either individual or a mix of planting categories which are suited to prevailing site conditions. This flexibility allows landowners to combine, as appropriate, commercial forest categories and those which provide the strongest environmental benefits.

Agroforestry (GPC 11) is a relatively new category option tion that combines farming and forestry working together in a mutually beneficial way. Silvopasture is a type of agroforestry involving the growing of wider spaced high-quality trees managed to integrate with livestock production and grass growth.

Financial Fitness

Forest can play a significant role in enhancing financial fitness on the farm. When you are considering the permanent land-use change that is forestry, it is also important to look beyond annual forestry premiums. Gaining an appreciation of the potential financial returns from future harvests is critical. These returns depend on a range of factors including the tree species selected, forest productivity (yield class) and its future management. In general, productive conifer species with a relatively short forest cycle (rotation) provide the highest financial returns.

The Teagasc Forest Investment Valuation Estimator (FIVE) is a beneficial tool used by forestry advisors in collaboration with clients to help inform decision-making in relation to potential land use and forestry. Adopting a whole-farm planning approach is also essential when assessing the options for forestry planning and integration on the farm. This requires analysis of how planting land may interact with farm enterprise combinations, farm schemes/supports and future succession planning. For example, the capacity for forestry parcels to also retain the Basic Payment, subject to eligibility conditions, is a key financial farm benefit.

Carbon benefits

The planting of new forests is also a significant land-based measure to help address the effects of climate change. Forests play an important role in the capture and removal of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and subsequent storage in forest biomass and soils, a process called sequestration. While not a silver bullet, f arm forests and woodlands, in appropriate locations, can significantly benefit the carbon efficiency and green credentials of farm businesses including reducing their carbon footprint.

urn:contentItem:68F2-Y4R1-DYS1-01CD-00000-00The soapmakers who are regenerating a farm in Co Meath2023-06-10T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:05:54ZLexisNexisSATURDAY MAGAZINEPg. 25The soapmakers who are regenerating a farm in Co Meath

There's a 30-acre field in Co Meath that's about to become five small ones, thanks to local entrepreneurs Donagh and Gemma Quigley. The founders of the Handmade Soap Company have bought a farm 2km from their factory in Slane village. The couple, who started making soap in their kitchen 13 years ago, have an ambition to create a profitable regenerative farm.

"With our business, we're always trying to practise what we're preaching," Quigley explains. "We just got a B Corp Cert." This is no small achievement. B Corp is a rigorous inspection standard which audits a company's environmental and social impact. "We want to carry that ethos over to the food supply."

The huge question of how to produce food without degrading soil while making a profit and enabling the land to sequester carbon and improve water quality was behind the decision to buy the farm. It's not a hobby farm, though. "Land isn't cheap so we have to get a return," Quigley says.

They looked up maps from the 18th century and found that the large perennial ryegrass field was once five smaller fields, divided by hedgerows. Replanting that hedgerow system will be one of the first steps. This year they will also put in an orchard of apples, pears, damson, plums and cherries, advised by local "apple grower extraordinaire" Mark Jenkinson from The Cider Mill.

The grandson of a farmer who grew up around farmers, Quigley says he isn't daunted by the prospect. He took a regenerative agriculture course at the Síolta Chroí centre in Co Monaghan. He is also inspired by Richard Perkins, who runs Ridgedale Farm in Sweden, an education centre based on making a living from small farms. Gemma is doing a deep dive into vegetable growing with a year-long market garden course.

They hope to plant a native woodland on part of the farm and to create a 5-acre agroforestry area where wide-spaced trees can be combined with grazing or growing. They have applied for a herd number and plan to buy 10 Dexter cattle. "We want Dexter because of their [smaller] size which means they can stay out all year round," without damaging the soil, he says.

Strip or mob grazing will mean the animals move between the small fields, a technique that can help boost biodiversity rather than just rewilding.

"We've planted an Irish wildflower mix, a perennial mix across 2 acres," Quigley says. The 30 acres has been pasture land for the previous two decades, heavily fertilised with nitrogen fertiliser and low in biodiversity. That's all about to change.

urn:contentItem:6531-YH71-DYS1-01W8-00000-00Hopefully Ireland is beginning to better understand the benefits of native trees2022-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisSATURDAY MAGAZINEPg. 9Hopefully Ireland is beginning to better understand the benefits of native treesCatherine Cleary

How was National Tree Week for you? Maybe you saw some of our "Meet the Trees" videos shot to the soundtrack of Dublin traffic at our nursery in The Digital Hub. Most of us can probably identify car logos more easily than we can tell a spindle from a hawthorn.

Irish trees and shrubs have long been a Cinderella ingredient in garden centres. As one nursery owner put it: "Laurel hedge, lawn, tarmac drive," are the elements a lot of his customers want in their gardens.

We hope the dial is moving and we are beginning to better understand the benefits and beauty of native trees and shrubs. They require much less maintenance than a lawn and we have a deep connection to them.

A tree like a birch supports hundreds of species of insects and countless soil microbes, all of which have evolved to work in harmony with the tree which was one of the first to take root here after the last ice age.

Rowan trees, or the mountain ash as they're known, were traditionally planted beside houses to ward off evil. Rowan berries are packed with vitamin C and arrive just in time for cold and flu season when our immune systems need a boost. They provide the tartness of a citrus fruit for rowanberry marmalade.

Foraging rowan berries is one thing but knitting trees into healthy large-scale food production is the ambitious and exciting aim of the Irish Agroforestry Forum. We pride ourselves on our ability to grow grass but given its choice Irish soil would move from grass to trees to forests, and combining the two makes for a far richer and more sustainable food system than monoculture dairy prairies.

Agroforestry is a no-brainer for Irish farming. Trees grow brilliantly on the island. Biodiversity loss can be halted, watercourses are protected as tree roots absorb excess nutrients that otherwise end up in groundwater. Carbon storage in the soils, crops and trees are a huge part of the system, and animal welfare is better. Cattle browsing on leaf material have fewer mineral deficiencies and reduced methane emissions.

Agroforestry can extend the growing season by up to 15 weeks, meaning animals are housed for less time, saving farmers money and reducing ammonia emissions.

"With carefully planned silvopasture all farms could integrate trees into their operations with minimal loss in pasture area and produce integrated harvests of timber or tree crops, all the while mitigating emissions, enhancing the environment and increasing farm resilience to climate challenges," the IAF said last week as it launched its new website, irishagroforestry.ie. As fertiliser costs spiral, there is no better time for farmers to spend time thinking about a new approach to trees.

Catherine Cleary is co-founder of Pocket Forests

After playing host to a very successful "Sheep 23" event, our sights are firmly fixed on preparing for the next show we are hosting, on Thursday July 20 we will be hosting the Energy and Farm Diversification Show.

For many years we hosted the Energy in Ag show which was a very successful farm energy show mainly focusing on reducing energy needs and promoting renewable energy sources and technologies. This year the show has been expanded to also include farm diversification.

With many industry stakeholders and public figures in attendance there promises to be much heated debate again this year. Last year's opening speeches and debates did not disappoint. Once the opening speeches and debates are finished everyone in attendance will be free to roam. The two main themes will be:

1. Diversification into energy, leisure, hospitality, food and tourism.

2. Reduction of energy consumption and increasing the production of renewable energy on farms

Exhibition Stands

There will be a large number of exhibitors who will be showing off the latest technology and products available to help in the reduction of energy use and in the production of renewables and well as consultancy companies eager to promote the services they offer.

In the Expo Arena there will be three different tracks, each will host eight to nine talks during the course of the day

* Track 1: Energy in Agriculture. Nine different talks focusing on, on farm energy use and production, biomass, anaerobic digestion and more

* Track 2: Farm diversification. Nine talks on, all aspects of farm diversification

* Track 3: Smart climate use. Eight different talks about, organic farming, energy crops, agroforestry, hemp, carbon farming and more.

Demos

There will be five different demos during the day

* 1. On-farm anaerobic digester demo: A conversation with questions and answers session about on-farm anaerobic digestion, in particular small-scale digestion and the future of anaerobic digestion in Ireland.

* 2. PV installation and Managing energy on farm: Demo on roof-mounted and ground-mounted solar installations with discussion focusing on TAMS, funding, technology, grid connections, finance as well as on-farm energy storage options.

* 3. Energy crops and biomass demo: A look at Gurteen's own on-farm biomass facilities followed by a talk on biomass crops and forestry followed by a discussion on research and markets for biomass.

* 4. Alternative and maximising farm organic fertiliser demo: A focus on reducing dependency on chemical fertiliser through the use of composting, maximising on-farm organic fertilisers as well as a look at alternative fertilisers

* 5. A discussion about commercial diversification options, ideal for anyone interested in or already engaged in on-farm diversification.

The show promises to be a huge source of information and inspiration, with discussion and debate, demos and diversification with a chance to network and learn for everyone interested in agriculture, the environment or energy conservation. We'll hopefully see your there in Gurteen College from 08:30 to 17:30 on Thursday the 20th of July. For more information or to pre-register for this free show please visit www.energyandfarmdiversificationshow.com

urn:contentItem:68V5-Y3P1-DYTY-C0R8-00000-00Financial gain and chance to help nature drove Farm Forestry Award winner2023-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMING;NEWSPg. 20Financial gain and chance to help nature drove Farm Forestry Award winnerSTEVEN MEYEN

Farming full-time on 53 hectares in Ballinamore, Co Leitrim, Sean Creamer manages a suckler herd and a young mixed forestry enterprise.

In 2016, Sean decided to plant forestry along the recently re-developed Shannon Erne waterway on land which had become challenging for farming.

He identified forestry as a steady and reliable income stream but also an opportunity to grow quality timber and enhance local biodiversity and landscape.

As a strong advocate of farmers working with the environment, Sean sees the impact of the forest going far beyond the financial gain with real benefits for biodiversity, animal welfare, water quality and carbon storage.

Sean is the winner of the 2023 RDS Teagasc Farm Forestry Award. On receiving the recognition, he said, "I am delighted to receive this award. Not only is the forest allowing our farm to be more financially sustainable but it is also really helping environmentally, which is something I strongly believe in."

The RDS Teagasc Farm Forestry Award category recognises those working farmers who are successfully meeting the challenge of integrating forestry on their farms to fully realise the many and rich benefits of trees.

It acknowledges the farmer's role in future-proofing the family farm through the integration of forestry and farming enterprises and managing and promoting the wider benefits of forests.

"Achieving a better work life balance", "restoring biodiversity and scenic value" and "improving farm sustainability by enabling the leasing of better land" - these are some of the rewards of integrating forestry and farming as expressed by previous winners of the award. What will yours be?

If you want to follow in Sean's footsteps and you believe that your forest has what it takes to win an RDS Teagasc Farm Forestry Award then follow the link below for further information and application forms for the 2024 awards.

To be eligible to enter, you need to be actively farming, and your farm forest has to be at least four hectares in size and between five and 15 years of age.

A very interesting development this year is that beside a more 'traditional' broadleaf or conifer forest, entries are now also invited from farmers who have agroforestry or reforestation sites on the farm.

The winner will receive (EURO)2,000 and an RDS Silver Medal. The runner-up will receive (EURO)1,000 and an RDS Certificate of Merit.

The RDS Forest and Woodland Awards are Ireland's national forestry awards.

They recognise and reward farmers and woodland owners who are employing the principles of climate-smart agriculture on their properties including sound commercial management, environmental protection and encouragement of biodiversity.

In addition to the Teagasc Farm Forestry Award, there are also award categories for Production Forestry, Community Woodlands and Native Woodland Conservation.

Further details on all award categories and application forms are available on the RDS website, see www.rds.ie/rds-foundation/agriculture/ rds-spring-awards/forestry-awards. Closing date for applications is Friday, August 25, 2023.

Steven Meyen is a Teagasc forestry advisor based in Ballybofey; steven.meyen@teagasc.ie

urn:contentItem:69KB-Y641-DYRW-V3MG-00000-00Euro farmers urged to follow Irish model2023-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMINGNEWSPg. 7Euro farmers urged to follow Irish modelStephen Cadogan

Even as pressure comes on Irish grass-based farming for environmental reasons, livestock farmers are being helped by the EU to feed their animals more on grass, in order to cut their environmental footprint and ensure high-quality foods.

There's a move away from the environmental and social costs of the grain-based cattle diets which grow animals faster and which traditionally produced cheaper meat and milk.

The grains are often imported from far-away countries, adding transport emissions to their cost. Some of the grain crops are cultivated on land created by cutting down tropical forests, further contributing to climate change, releasing carbon stored in trees, and causing biodiversity loss. And these grains cut into much-needed supplies of food for people worldwide.

Now a 9m EU-funded project called Pathways promotes more sustainable agricultural practices, including pasture-based farming. It runs for five years, until the end of August 2026.

Farmers in the project have created a special meat and dairy label to inform consumers of the pasture production method and its health benefits, which include lower fat and higher vitamin levels.

Pathways include British, German, Italian, and Swedish livestock farmers, feeding some of their herds' grass-based diets, albeit with some grains fed also.

Other environmental benefits claimed for grass are that grazing animals return nutrients to the soil through faeces and urine, and such pastures can absorb carbon from the atmosphere, especially if agroforestry is practiced.

In total, 31 research partners from 12 countries are helping 15 groups of livestock farms reduce their environmental footprint. The partners include the Arla Foods dairy company in Denmark, Danone Nutricia Research in France, Ghent University in Belgium, and the Switzerland-based Research Institute for Organic Farming.

The thinking behind the project is that farmers must supply more food as populations grow, by sustainable methods with minimal environmental impact, while ensuring food afety and animal welfare.

Consumer preferences, diet choices, and willingness to pay will be researched. Life cycle emissions and economic analysis of trade and supply chain impacts will also be part of the project. Economic sustainability of the livestock sector in the EU will also be investigated - whether feeding cows grass offers farmers more than environmental benefits, for example, if they can sell their products at a premium price.

Of course, for Irish farmers, it is all like "teaching grandmother to suck eggs". Grass is the secret of Irish livestock farmers, particularly milk producers, because we can grow up to 14 tonnes per hectare of grass per year (measured as feed dry matter).

Some of our ideas come from New Zealand, also pasture based with seasonal calving and grazing pasture throughout the year. Despite relatively low average milk yields, lower input costs keep the dairy industries globally competitive in Ireland and New Zealand.

It's not surprising that continental Europe is latching into such ideas, such as the Pathways farmers relying more on grass. Dairy farmers in most EU countries complain that their traditional indoor-based production isn't competitive at the milk prices of recent years. Utilising grass better would be a profitable move, in areas that can grow grass.

Nor is it surprising that one of the continent's best known pasture-based farms could be described as an Ireland-New Zealand joint venture.

Grasmilch Brandenburg, 60km west of Berlin, owned by Irish brothers Paul and Stephen Costello, produces 100% grass-fed milk. Since 2014, they have modernised the farm to carry about 850 New Zealand-bred dairy cows which graze 10 months, with two months on silage.

In November 2021, the farm won the Ceres Award for Sustainable Agriculture in Germany, with praise for its reduction in imported feeds, grassland sequestering more carbon, and lower energy requirements because cows are outside.

The farm uses New Zealand agricultural technology, including Gallagher fences and a Waikato Milking Systems 60-bail rotary parlour. But the farm also uses a lot of Irish products, such as water troughs from Murphy Concrete Products, McHale balers, Wilson engineering bale transporters. Many of the farm's cows came from Ireland. Feed supplements from Terra Nutritech and Shamrock Enterprises are used.

The cows average 440 kg of milk solids, for a targeted 800kg of concentrates (but more than 900kg was fed last year, due to drought hitting grass growth). However, grass growth in 2021 was 13.3 tonnes of dry matter per hectare.

The cows are bred using LIC genetics from New Zealand and are 50% Holstein and 50% Jersey, much smaller than German cows.

Farm manager Kevin Kearns. from Co Cork, has said, "I think there is a lot of potential here for the German farmers to set up a more New Zealand-like system, but they just need the help and they need the advice on it." Farmers come from all over the EU to see how it is done at Grasmilch Brandenburg.

The 735-hectare farm is unique to the state of Brandenburg, producing pasture-based milk for local consumers.

urn:contentItem:6838-SXX1-DYTY-C53J-00000-00Broaden your horizons by signing up your farm for an EIP project2023-04-25T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMING;NEWSPg. 13Broaden your horizons by signing up your farm for an EIP projectAndrew Bergin

The agricultural European Innovation Partnership (EIP-AGRI) works to foster competitive and sustainable farming and forestry that "achieves more and better from less".

EIPs fundamentally provide money to bring different groups together to try out an innovative idea. The outcomes are publicly available.

There's lots of paperwork, as there has to to be when EU funds are spent, and there is no shortage of oversight.

EIP projects generally involve farmers and a research institute or other body that has the resources and experience to deal with the bureaucracy.

Our farm is involved in two EIPs that will finish this year (the projects are wound up after a maximum of five years ) and we have just signed up for another.

The Danu EIP project involves 16 individuals who have come together to learn about and carry out the basic principles of biological farming, in an effort to produce food, feed and forages of high nutritional quality.

Twelve farms are in the fifth year of running trials, and an enormous amount has been learnt. If you want to hear about what we have been doing, there are two open days - on Thursday, June 15 on a dairy farm in Rathangan and the next day on a crop farm in Grangecon.

If you bring an open mind you will find plenty to encourage you, and we will try to help you to avoid some of the pitfalls.

The Protecting Farmland Pollinators EIP project aims to develop a whole- farm pollinator scoring system and identify what management practices on Irish farmland benefit pollinators.

It is led by a team from the National Biodiversity Data Centre, and 40 farms around Kildare are involved. We have learned so much about pollinators and how simple it can be to make our farms friendlier for them. The project website explains this clearly.

To break the monotony of the corn belt of south Kildare I planted some trees a few years ago. I knew very little about trees, and Trees on the Land provided advice and native tree bundles.

This is a not-for-profit organisation that supports anybody who has the space to plant a tree.

I went back to them for advice on more planting and eventually signed up to participate in their agroforestry EIP. This will look at the integration of forestry into an arable farm in my case and fits in well with my own objectives.

We are almost finished planting 800 trees - a mix of fruit, nut and timber trees - around two fields and are assembling the baseline data so that we can measure their effect on the environment.

EIPs are collaborations and you can get a lot out of them if you put a bit of effort in. Working with a team means you don't always get your own way, but your own way isn't always the best way.

The experience has broadened my horizons and, with a bit of luck, I might be around to see the trees narrow them again.

Andrew Bergin is a tillage farmer based near Athy, Co Kildare

urn:contentItem:67T5-J951-JC8Y-848R-00000-00'There are two main reasons for burning land, both involve cash'2023-03-18T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisSATURDAY MAGAZINEPg. 23'There are two main reasons for burning land, both involve cash'

To a non-farmer it's hard to see the sense in setting fire to land. Put aside the loss of wildlife, danger of burning down human homes, the pollution and disastrous carbon emissions from burning peatland, why would you set fire to your asset? The Irish Wildlife Trust did a deep dive into land burning and found lots of rules but very little implementation. This year hillsides in West Cork and Kerry blazed again, to the exhaustion of fire fighters and the despair of wildlife and nature lovers.

There are two main reasons for burning and both involve cold hard cash. Torching a gorse-laden hill is cheap (until it's not, when you factor in loss of livestock, property or people hours spent fighting fires). And here's the head melt: the taxpayer funded farm payments system incentivised it. But now that game has changed. And everyone can benefit.

I learned more about this thanks to Maureen Kilgore. She's a sheep farmer and co-ordinator of the Irish Agroforestry Forum (IAF). We worked together on a series of podcasts called Conversation Beneath the Trees and she is a huge source of knowledge on nature-friendly farming and farmers.

Earlier this month Kilgore was busy preparing for lambing. "We lamb outdoors, the sheep usually [lamb] next to a hedgerow, the fallen leaves from the autumn providing a bed and the birds in the trees overhead serenading each lamb," she wrote in an IAF newsletter. "The hedgerows are now chattering away all day, full of nesting birds."

That evocative description of hedgerows "chattering away" contrasts so strongly to the pictures of silent scorched earth or the box cut hedgerows where knee-high bare sticks remain of what was once a happy wildlife habitat.

The good news is that the basic farm payment rules have changed, Kilgore explains. Last year "in order to be eligible for basic payment, a land parcel could not have more than 10 per cent of what were classified as ineligible features such as scrub, trees, copses, woodland habitat and rock," she says. That has now been increased up to 50 per cent.

"This change will also discourage farmers from removing woodland scrub and gorse from farmland, both of which are valuable for wildlife as well as shelter and fodder for livestock," Kilgore says.

"Woodland scrub also contributes significantly to carbon capture, therefore it is important to retain it and allow food production to continue on the land."

The system change has the potential to put a rewilding or nature-friendly payment into the pockets of farmers.

From March 1st it became illegal to burn or cut hedgerows and scrub as the annual moratorium to protect nesting birds began. Maybe November rolls around, and it becomes legal again, it will no longer be logical to slash and burn nature-rich habitats off the map from both an economic and an environmental point of view.

urn:contentItem:67CG-MSN1-JCBW-N2TG-00000-00'I'm creating space for nature - and enhancing production'2023-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 43'I'm creating space for nature - and enhancing production'Colm McGuirk

ALL farmers big and small will have to do their bit to avoid environmental catastrophe, and many already are.

Nia O'Malley farms 60 hectares in the Slieve Aughty Mountains in Co. Galway. She is an ambassador of Farming for Nature - a network of almost 100 farmers who aim to operate 'in a way that will improve the natural health of the countryside'.

She has taken a number of eco-minded measures on her farm and found that they don't need to represent a sacrifice - and most of them make sense in farming terms too.

After becoming involved with the Hen Harrier Project in 2018 - named after the bird whose presence indicates strong biodiversity - she now grazes cattle up the mountain, where farmers previously 'had learned that there's no value so just ignored' it.

Nia says: 'Molinia grass was taking over the whole of this mountain area. Not only is it a fire risk, but also there's a loss of biodiversity because the ground-nesting birds would need that sort of variance in height.'

The innovative farmer has planted lots of hedgerow and tree lines since taking over the family farm in 2010.

'I'm putting in natural shelterbelts for my animals, but by doing that you're also enhancing biodiversity. You're creating wildlife corridors through your land.'

She has also introduced an element of silvopasture agroforestry - integrating trees with grazing animals - on some of the wetter patches of her land. 'They go hand in hand,' she said. 'I'm creating space for nature, but I'm also enhancing production.'

And it isn't all about planting; Nia and other hill land farmers are encouraged to snip or pull the numerous sapling conifers that sprout up 'all over the mountains and bogs', which allows the bog to maintain its carbon storage function.

'They'll eventually grow into mature trees, but what happens there is, as that tree is growing it's actually drying out the bog, and when you have a bog drying out you get a release of carbon. Peatland actually stores twice as much carbon as forestry, so there should be more measures to restore our peatlands.'

The Hen Harrier Project taught Nia the value of cutting fields later in the year than usual.

'This allows the seedheads to form on the different grasses and different flowers and then they disperse them around August time. The different flowers affect the fertility and the structure of the land, so you're creating more fertile lands,' she explained.

urn:contentItem:67XT-CWY1-DYTY-C3G5-00000-00Using technology to learn how to manage diverse forests2023-04-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisFARMING;NEWSPg. 20Using technology to learn how to manage diverse forestsSteven Meyen

Recent developments in European and national policy are promoting diverse and integrated management.

The aim is to enhance forest resilience in the face of climate disruption and sustain timber production while delivering a range of ecosystem services.

A balanced mix of forest management systems is required to cater for the diversity of forest types, site conditions and, in particular, owner objectives. Continuous cover forestry CCF is a forest management approach suitable to both conifers and broadleaves. It allows for the production of commercial timber while retaining a forest cover at all times.

It often relies on harnessing natural forest processes such as natural regeneration of trees, mixed species, increased biodiversity and natural forest development.

Stand stability is an important factor in considering transforming to CCF systems. It is not an option for all sites as issues with elevation and soil quality might undermine forest wind stability during the transformation process.

Sheltered sites with free-draining soils are most suited.

High-deer-density sites are also difficult to transform to CCF due to browsing of young trees.

CCF systems, on suitable sites, offer a possible alternative to the widely practised clearfell/replant system where trees are harvested all at once at the end of the rotation. This is then followed by one replanting operation.

Higher structural diversity and species diversity allow CCF systems to integrate timber production with a high level of ecosystem services.

These services include soil protection, long-term and stable carbon storage, water protection, landscape, recreation and habitat refuge for a wide range of woodland species of flora, fauna and fungi.

Marteloscope training forests Marteloscopes are specially prepared forest plots, ranging from 0.4ha to 1ha, which are commonly used across Europe for training participants in tree selection and tree marking.

The name comes from the French martelage meaning, 'hammering' - traditionally trees were marked for thinning across Europe, using a purpose-built hammering tool.

The European Forest Institute (EFI) has enhanced marteloscope plot usage in recent years with specially designed software for use on tablets (pictured).

Every tree is numbered, measured and its timber and biodiversity values estimated. Tablets are used to carry out thinning simulations, allowing participants to practise new skills and test out in real-time different management options ranging from conventional clearfell to CCF.

Marteloscopes help equip forest owners with the skills to choose the most appropriate management systems to meet their objectives and enhance the production and biodiversity value of each forest.

Teagasc's Forestry Development Department has partnered with the EFI, in collaboration with Coillte and Pro Silva Ireland, to make this resource available in Ireland to private forest owners, foresters, students and other interested groups.

Training workshops Teagasc's Forestry Development Department is running a new programme of marteloscope forest management workshops, at Oak

Park Research Centre, Carlow on April 19, May 3 and May 17.

These workshops focus on different forest management scenarios, enable attendees to practise selecting trees by their timber quality, vitality and biodiversity value and show how management can help integrate production with biodiversity and the other many important services.

For further details and to register, visit www.teagasc.ie/forestry Forest walks Teagasc in association with the Department are organising a nationwide series of forest walks from April 12-28, which will explore a wide range of opportunities for new forest creation.

Forestry experts will discuss different forest types such as native forests, agroforestry and mixed high forests. See www.teagasc.ie/forestwalks Steven Meyen is a Teagasc forestry advisor based in Ballybofey; steven.meyen@teagasc.ie

urn:contentItem:67SK-KJ41-DYRW-V1FY-00000-00Gorse fires pose 'risk to life', warn climate advisers2023-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Gorse fires pose 'risk to life', warn climate advisersPádraig Hoare, Environment Correspondent

Use of controlled burning to manage vegetation "poses a significant risk to life, property, and biodiversity", the country's Climate Change Advisory Council (CCAC) has warned.

Following a weekend of gorse fires that threatened large swathes of the likes of West Cork and Kerry, there has been palpable anger in rural communities about the unforeseen impact of so-called controlled burning.

The CCAC, an independent advisory body set up under the 2015 Climate Act to advise on Ireland making the transition to a low carbon economy by 2050, said the use of controlled fire "is not recommended best practice in most circumstances".

"Although not the only cause of wildfires, the use of controlled fire to manage vegetation creates a substantial risk of accidental propagation of fire into adjacent lands, particularly forest and peatland areas. It also poses a significant risk to life, property, and biodiversity," the CCAC said.

Farmers need to be included in policymaking to move away from the practice, it added.

"A high proportion of Ireland's forest land is in private ownership, and this is largely ownership within the farming community.

"Hence, current ambition for forest management, afforestation, and agroforestry will require strong engagement from the whole farming community.

"Management across all vegetation and land uses must be sensitive to the risk of others in the community, and when properly planned and managed will mitigate against wildfire, increase resilience and can be highly cost-effective."

Widespread fires impact on Ireland's carbon emissions, with fires throughout the country in 2017 leading to reported emissions of 1.9m tonnes of carbon dioxide, the CCAC warned.

Maynooth University professor of geography (climate change), Peter Thorne, said "habitual burning of the land is the very worst thing that can be done from an environmental perspective".

"Much of that upland area is upland peat bogs, that's massive carbon stores gained over thousands of years that we are willingly letting into the atmosphere. I shudder to think how many tonnes of CO2 would have been emitted. It's something you see across Ireland and the UK, environmentally it is hugely damaging.

"I don't think the answer is to relax the banning season - the answer, if anything, is to restrict it even more and phase it out entirely," he said.

However, farmers and landowners need incentivising to change practices rather than being penalised, he said.

"There are other livelihoods and ways of using that land, and this comes down to the just transition. You can't legislate your way out of it, you have to win hearts and minds and come up with viable alternatives for people."

"Just transition" is the term used to describe making sure employment opportunities and societal benefits are present for those who may live and work in communities tied to legacy industries, such as coal mining and peat extraction.

Agriculture Minister Charlie McConalogue said "the farming community has a central role to play in the control of fire in our landscapes through the management of land" but warned landowners and members of the public not to carry out any illegal burning of land during spring and summer.

VINEYARDS in the southeast, wild woodlands in the west, extensive floodplains in the midlands woodlands… a leading environmental expert has revealed how the Irish countryside will radically transform over the next three decades in response to climate change.

Dr James Moran, is a senior lecturer in ecology and biology at Atlantic Technological University. He says our countryside in 2050 will be an assortment of solar farms, agroforests, floodplains and even vineyards interspersed among our pastures and croplands.

Dr Moran paints a vivid picture of a vastly changed landscape that will 'reflect more the underlying geology and soils and climatic condition', rather than the expansive dairy and tillage farmland currently common across many parts of the country.

'Essentially we'll be adapting our land use an awful lot more to the capacity of the land,' Dr Moran told the Irish Mail on Sunday.

'It takes an awful lot of inputs and pushing against the land to convert it into something other than its natural state. We've been reclaiming peat lands, trying to push wetland into drier land for other uses, but we simply won't be able to do this any longer because we have rising sea levels, so where are we going to drain the water to?'

Continuing to drain lands would lead to 'more and more flooding with extreme flooding events in the lowlands where our urban populations and rural towns are concentrated and that simply just won't be acceptable'.

Dr Moran is a member of the National Biodiversity Forum; the National Rural Network sub-committee on Biodiversity, Environmental Challenges and LIFE Programmes; the

Uplands Management Board of the Heritage Council; and board member of European Results Based Payments Network.

Projecting to a future in which biodiversity and environmental targets are met and we still contribute to global food supplies - and taking into account the inevitabilities of climate change - he said the landscape as we know it will be transformed over the next three decades.

'In the deeper, more fertile soils - which are very suitable for production of high quantities of food and fibre - we're going to see an awful lot more cropland, particularly in the east of the country where there are possibly more favourable climatic conditions. But it's going to be interspersed with some pastures as well and hedgerows and tree lines and pockets of mixed woodland.'

Farms will move to an integrated crop-livestock system - in which crop and livestock use the same land over time to complement each other and get the best out of the land.

And he said the frightening temperature increases we are already 'locked into' could lead to one silver lining for wine lovers, particularly in the sunny southeast.

'We'll be starting to see some farmers innovating with much more diverse cropland, and we might even see a couple of vineyards pop- ping up,' said the lecturer, who has a background in dairy farming.

'It's not that you're going to see them everywhere, but you'll see some farmers starting to experiment with these and other permanent crops as well.'

Ireland currently has a small number of wine makers, including one in Lusk, Co Dublin, run by David Llewellyn. It produces a rich Cabernet-Merlot called Lusca, but Dr Moran indicated that climate change may see more vineyards in warmer parts of the country.

Moving across to Munster, where land is less suitable for tillage, we can expect to see 'still some cropland but more of a dominance of livestock production'.

Additional pockets of wetlands will be a more prominent feature of the landscape thanks to more intensive rainfall, while commitments to reforestation and promotion of biodiversity will lead to 'more pockets of trees and extensive hedgerow networks'.

'As you're driving through the midlands and around areas of the Shannon in particular, you're going to see - particularly at this time of year - more extensive floodplains on the past sites of the industrial peatlands,' Dr Moran added.

'pockets of pastureland and woodland and young forests'.

The western lowlands of East Galway, Mayo and Roscommon will be 'a greater mix of young forests and agroforestry [which integrates trees with crops and livestock] interspersed among the pastures, with also pockets of peat lands and wetlands'.

On higher ground, particularly in the west, 'you'll see a much more diverse mix of vegetation cover - so you'll see semi-natural woodlands and sheltered areas' with 'pockets

This will be interspersed with renewable energy production, mainly wind and solar, as well as of relatively intensive farmland still there as well.

'But generally, there will be more heathland and tree cover on the side of the hills. Livestock will still be a significant feature across the landscape, but in general I think you'll have a much more wooded feel to the country.'

Dr Moran anticipates a similar picture of land use and land cover more reflective of the underlying natural capacity in Ulster.

He said we'll see a slight increase in cropland in fertile deeper soils (eastern and central areas, and areas around the Foyle in the west) but livestock production will still dominate.

'Both cropland and pastures in these areas will be interspersed by a greater density of treelines, hedgerows and small pockets of woodland. The rest of the lowland areas and some foothills will be dominated by pastureland with a greater mix of woodland and agroforestry, interspersed with some peatlands and wetland.'

Wind turbines and solar farms will also be more common, but 'hopefully strategically placed'.

While Dr Moran's projections will require major buy-in from farmers, the climate expert said he is confident they 'can do it with the correct supports' in place.

'They're more attuned to the environment and the weather conditions than any other industry in the country,' he stressed.

He described 'a lot of actions in process at a relatively small scale' from farmers around the country, particularly in the Farming For Nature network - an initiative set up by landscape charity Burrenbeo Trust in 2018 which helps farmers adjust to more eco-conscious farming.

Dr Moran said his ostensibly optimistic outlook comes from a standpoint that 'continuing on with business as usual doesn't bear thinking about'. He told the Irish Mail on Sunday: 'If we continue on with the way we're going, we're looking at catastrophic situations. If we start acting sooner rather than later, we will achieve it. But if we don't start acting now, we definitely will be acting in 2035, 2040 because society will be starting to break down.'

However even his best-case scenario predictions allow for some negative outcomes. 'In some places you're going to see where infrastructure couldn't be protected from the worst of the extreme weather events,' he acknowledged.

'So I think you will see pockets of unfavourable looking situations as well as you're driving across the country in 2050, but hopefully not as much as we could have if we act now.'

urn:contentItem:66J1-BH41-JDRT-217T-00000-00Nestle revamps coffee sustainability plans2022-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:05:54ZLexisNexisARTICLEnewsdocumentNestle revamps coffee sustainability plansReuters::WIRE::

Food giant Nestle has today pledged to spend over 1 billion Swiss francs ($1.01 billion) by 2030 on efforts to source coffee sustainably.

This is more than double its previous pledge, as challenges linked to climate change pose particular risks for the bean.

Study after study has shown that by 2050 roughly half the land currently used to grow coffee, especially that of the high quality arabica variety, could be unproductive thanks to rising temperatures, drought and disease.

Multinationals are meanwhile facing increased reputational and legal pressure from consumers and governments alike to clean up their global supply chains in the fight against climate change.

The European Commission has proposed several laws aimed at preventing and, in the case of forced labour, banning the import and use of products linked to environmental and human rights abuses.

Nestle has already pledged to source all its coffee sustainably by 2025.

It said it is now also aiming, by that date, for 20% of its coffee to be grown using 'regenerative' agricultural practices as part of its new NESCAFÉ Plan 2030.

These include planting cover crops to protect soil, using organic fertilisers to improve soil fertility and increasing the use of agroforestry and intercropping to preserve biodiversity.

The measures have the aim of halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.

The company, announcing its plan to double spending on sustainable coffee sourcing, said it is "committed to supporting farmers who take on the risks and costs associated with the move to regenerative agriculture", and will provide programmes aimed at helping them improve their income.

A major coffee report published last year said there is little evidence efforts by the world's top coffee roasters and traders to prevent human rights and environmental abuses are having any impact, with most farmers operating at a loss and unable to produce sustainably.

The coffee sector is valued at $200 billion-$250 billion a year at the retail level, according to the report.

But producing countries receive less than 10% of that value when exporting beans, and farmers even less than that.

Around 125 million people around the world depend on coffee for their livelihoods, while an estimated 80% of coffee-farming families live at or below the poverty line, according to non-profit organisations Fairtrade and Technoserve.

urn:contentItem:68PH-XKK1-DYS1-003H-00000-00Nature is thriving in a sodden patch of Roscommon2023-07-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisWEEKENDPg. 7Nature is thriving in a sodden patch of RoscommonThere is a mistaken idea in the west of Ireland that the wet ground is 'marginal', 'poor' and 'unproductive'

Clambering over a wire fence, I step into the wet woodland. And there it is, a flash mob of blooming orchids. The common spotted orchid's slender, tapering stems rise out of the ground, adorned with elliptical leaves; the cone-shaped flower apex is varied in colour, from a hint of pink to something reminiscent of lilac. A snow-white variety, O'Kelly's spotted-orchid, is scattered between them and exudes a sweet scent.

This alder wood runs through the centre of Keith and Caroline Brennan's 12-acre farm in the corner of north Roscommon, tucked between the Kilronan mountains on one side and the soft wetlands of Leitrim on the other. Keith was born and raised in Dublin's Liberties - in the 1911 census, his ancestors lived on Bride Street - and the prospect of owning land was enticing. Following the economic crash, the Brennans whittled down the options: a two-bedroom house in Drimnagh or a clod of Roscommon soil? They went with life on the land.

Keith wanted to reimagine the farm's potential and find a way to map out an economically viable future that could withstand the immense climatic uncertainties ahead. If he flattened the land and spread chemical fertiliser, then set it to green grass or planted a forestry crop, he would maximise the public subsidies on offer. But Keith preferred to farm under the assumption that natural resources are exhaustible; without nature, the land would quickly wear out. From the start, he saw his role as a farmer as being wider than just producing food. He would be a land manager and nature-creator as well.

It began with orchids. Wild orchids are remarkably patient and can lie dormant for years if environmental conditions aren't right. Their rhizomes and finger-shaped tubers remain alive - if a little sluggish - as they bide their time for more favourable circumstances to emerge.

His first move was to fence the alder wood to protect it from deer and his flock of diminutive Shetland sheep. The sheep were allowed in during the colder months (their grazing opened up space for the orchids to emerge), but as the sun warmed up in spring, he took them out to let the flowers grow. Within a year, orchids popped up.

We crouch down in the damp humidity of the wood. Among the wispy grasses, the orchids stand erect and sturdy. It's hard to imagine that they began life as dust-like seeds barely visible to the eye. These microscopic specks contain enough genes to develop but lack the nutrients for germination. To solve this, orchids and soil fungi engage in a quid pro quo relationship.

The fungi - such as the delicate, branch-like Tulasnella - colonise the seeds with thread-like filaments, which provide the orchids with enough nutrients to germinate. As the orchid grows upwards, it converts energy from the sun into sugars, which the fungi willingly absorb. Keith knows this delicate, finely tuned relationship is easily shattered by ploughing, spraying chemicals and adding fertiliser to the land.

Keith split the farm into acre-sized parcels of woodland, species-rich meadows, wild flower hay meadows, open hilly grassland and agroforestry. The small fields are separated by fencing and dense hedgerows of plums, crab apples, hazelnuts, elder, hawthorns, blackthorn and whitethorn, which act as a windbreak and also feed his bees and pigs. O'Kelly's orchids (named after Patrick O'Kelly, a colourful farmer and botanical expert from the early 1900s who discovered them in his native Ballyvaughan in the Burren) have spread throughout the farm.

Wild flower species

We stand in the wild flower hay meadow. The names of the species flow off Keith's tongue: stitchwort, foxgloves, bluebells, ragged robin, white clover, bird's-foot trefoil, devil's bit scabious, pimpernel, meadow vetchling, sheep's sorrel, yellow primrose, eyebright and cinquefoil. There are 61 wild flower species here. They support a multitude of insects, which are in turn eaten by the 41 species of birds that have made this land their home. In the summer, Keith cuts the meadows in succession and dries the flowers and grasses as hay, which is fed to the sheep over winter. The wildflowers continue to grow well into autumn.

What if, all those years ago, farmers had been paid to stay and manage the land for nature and food, at a similar rate to the money poured into tax-free publicly funded schemes for monoculture forestry?

A 120-acre Sitka spruce plantation, owned by Bank of Ireland, wraps around the farm. A few years ago sections were clear-felled and old farmhouses and stone-walled sheds that were previously hidden felt sun on their walls for the first time in years. In one townland that's now planted, 18 people had farmed the land.

These people died or drifted away - no doubt tempted by more favourable employment prospects elsewhere, or understandably indifferent to a future on the land. Still, a question remains: what if, all those years ago, farmers had been paid to stay and manage the land for nature and food, at a similar rate to the money poured into tax-free publicly funded schemes for monoculture forestry?

In a sense, one of the greatest problems about the land in this part of the west of Ireland - a mistaken idea that the ground is "marginal", "poor", "wet" and "unproductive" - is its greatest strength, for nature thrives in these conditions. We know we are facing catastrophic nature loss and unpredictable, extreme climate events. We'll probably turn to farmers as adept as Keith, and the lessons learned from rejuvenating these small fields, to restore life to our land in the future.

urn:contentItem:66V9-7481-JC8Y-80GK-00000-00Could animal-free 'dairy' offer a way forward?2022-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T22:06:04ZLexisNexisSATURDAY MAGAZINEPg. 21Could animal-free 'dairy' offer a way forward?

Less than 30 years ago a technology company was the fifth biggest brand in the world. It commanded two-thirds of the global market, employed tens of thousands of people and was valued at more than EUR 31 billion. It seemed untouchable. But the Kodak Film company filed for bankruptcy in 2012. Film faded "like an old photo", as the Economist put it. Phone cameras consigned those little black canisters that opened with a pop to history.

Today global food giants are buying into disruptive food technology, keen to avoid their own Kodak moment. New Zealand's dairy corporation Fonterra announced a start-up with Dutch bioscience company Royal DSM in August. The two had been quietly co-operating since before the pandemic. Their project? To commercialise precision fermentation.

There is no kimchi involved. Precision fermentation makes animal-free dairy by adding animal DNA to microbes like yeast, fungi, algae or bacteria and brewing them in vats to produce milk. "I would never eat that Frankenfood," you might say. But if you eat cheese you already do. Most rennet is now made by precision fermentation.

The next generation of eaters doesn't want to eat the products of a system with high carbon emissions, pollutants and the wholesale loss of living things from land dominated by ryegrass and ruminants. The consumer research is clear.

Significant hurdles including regulation, what to call these products and fears around its GMO nature still exist for the new food. Unlike digital cameras, the development does not have to sweep everything away. Fonterra has said their venture is intended to be complementary to farmed dairy.

But animal-free dairy is not weather-dependent. Fermentation factories can produce it anywhere in the world, which could make Ireland's niche as the best little country in the world to do dairy fade away.

In this headlong dash to a more sustainable future, there is still space for Irish dairy, done better. On a growing number of regenerative farms, small herds are fed on organic multi-species swards, agroforestry dairy farms where cows browse on tree hay. We have the models that can provide healthy futures for farmers.

The uncoupling of protein production from livestock farming will hinge on consumer acceptance. Unlike plant-based meat and dairy alternatives, these precision fermentation products taste like the animal version, according to their manufacturers. "Our products are not like cheese, they are cheese," Berlin-based company Formo says in its marketing.

Formo is eyeing 10 per cent of the European market by 2030. Freed up from relentless production demands, farmers can be paid to farm for nature, to allow soils to come back to life and become carbon sinks, a double win that could help keep the planet habitable. Heroes in wellies. How's that for a happy picture, to which we can all say cheese?
